Award.AwardTitle: Dynamical Effects in Heterogeneous Catalytic Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hua Guo of the University of New Mexico is supported by an award from the Theoretical and Computational Chemistry program to study fundamental issues related to the dynamics and mechanisms of reactions relevant to heterogeneous catalysis. Using theoretical and computational methods, Guo and his research group are elucidating experimentally observed mode- and bond-specificity in an important benchmark system for molecule-surface interactions, namely the dissociative chemisorption of methane on metal surfaces. The research requires the determination of the Born-Oppenheimer potential energy surface for the reaction using density functional theory, followed by multidimensional quantum dynamics calculations. These studies represent a systematic and comprehensive approach to fundamental surface reaction dynamics and are shedding much needed light on energy flow, activation mechanism, and the origin of the mode- and bond-selectivity.

Heterogeneous catalysis represents an important pillar in a modern chemical industry because of its role in the production of various chemicals ranging from fertilizers to plastics. It is also essential in many other vital areas such as environmental protection (e.g., catalytic converters in automobiles) and future energy technology (e.g., hydrogen fuel). Insights gained in these studies suggest future strategies to improve catalytic efficiency. In addition, these high-level theories offer benchmarks for more approximate dynamic models and stimulate theoretical studies of other surface reactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vital role of heterogeneous chemistry in modern society cannot be overstated. Indeed, many essential chemicals such as fertilizers are produced via heterogeneous catalysis. Such processes are also of great importance in many other areas such as environmental protection (e.g., catalytic converters in automobiles), future energy technology (e.g., hydrogen and methanol fuels), and materials science (chemical vapor deposition and optical lithography). As a result, chemistry at interfaces has huge economic and societal implications. Although great progress has been made in past decades, our understanding of the elementary steps involved in heterogeneous chemistry is still very limited. The lack of detailed mechanistic and dynamical knowledge remains a major obstacle for the development of new and more efficient interfacial reactions.

            With support by this NSF grant, the PI has led a comprehensive effort to develop state-of-the-art theoretical tools to study some gas-surface reactions. These tools include the development of multi-dimensional potential energy surfaces, which correlate geometric configuration of the system with energy, and quantum dynamical methods, which extract quantities that can be observed in experiments. These tools allowed the PI and his students to investigate two important reactions, namely the dissociative chemisorption of water and methane on metal surfaces. These processes are the initial and often slowest step in many industrial processes for making hydrogen fuel and other chemicals. As a result, a complete understanding of these reactions have important implications. The theoretical simulations of the reactions not only reproduced experimental observations, but also uncovered fundamental principles governing these processes. As a result, our knowledge has been greatly advanced.

            In addition to the research activities outlined above, the NSF grant also allowed the training of a number of students, thus contributing to the future STEM workforce. The PI has integrated the research results in to his educational endeavor. Outreach efforts have also been made in the local communities.
